verb.description: Take part or intervene in an activity without invitation or necessity.
examples: she tried not to interfere in her children's lives

verb.description: Prevent (a process or activity) from continuing or being carried out properly.
examples: a job would interfere with his studies

verb.description: Handle or adjust (something) without permission, especially so as to cause damage.
examples: he admitted interfering with a van

verb.description: (of light or other electromagnetic waveforms) mutually act upon each other and produce interference.
examples: light pulses interfere constructively in a fiber to emit a pulse

verb.description: (of a horse) knock one foot against the fetlock of another leg.

origin: Late Middle English: from Old French s'entreferir strike each other, from entre- between + ferir (from Latin ferire to strike).
